The apple is a sweet, edible fruit produced by an apple tree. Apple trees are cultivated worldwide, and are the most widely grown species in the genus Malus. The tree originated in Central Asia, where its wild ancestor, Malus sieversii, is still found today.

Apples are very good sources of antioxidants, vitamin C, and dietary fiber. The fiber content, while less than in most other fruits, helps regulate bowel movements and may thus reduce the risk of colon cancer.

Sugar is a carbohydrate that occurs naturally in every fruit and vegetable. It is a simple sugar, called a monosaccharide, which means that it is one of the smallest units of sugar and cannot be broken down into a simpler form.
Sugar is the generic name for sweet-tasting, soluble carbohydrates, many of which are used in food.
